title.narrative: Youth and Democracy - agents of change

description.narrative: Increase understanding among youth of democratic principles and the role of citizens and civil society in the formal, democratic decision making process. Strengthen youth ability to identify policies and issues needing change and to organize and influence policy-making through advocacy and citizen action.
Projektet bidrar till att ungdomars kunskap om demokratiska principer, och vikten av CS och individers aktiva roll i demokratiska processer stärks.

participating-org.narrative: DPNA/Development for People and Nature Association

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: DPNA and Mobaderoon has during the last three years managed to achieve targets and objectives set up for the last support from Sida 2013-2016. They have reached many young people inside Syria that are engaged in the community work, they have conducted several workshops in Lebanon and Turkey, they are providing safe spaces when needed to young people at risk and has proved to be flexible when needed. For example during year two, around 2000 members were committed to group meetings launching sixty-one social action projects. The social projects ranged from cleaning up your neighbourhood campaign, art workshops to making school books.
FADA highlighted the feasibility, and impact, of civil actions within uprisings and conflicts. The project managed to overcome the on-going daily challenges which continuously change with the Syrian Dynamics.
In total Mobaderoon has reached more than 8000 youth members in addition to a network of civil society organizations (CSOs) constituting several new born CBOs. A positive aspect was, despite political differences, geographical differences members of the network were able to ask for support from each other during the implementation of their small scale projects . . FADA’s main goal was to bring the Syrian Youth to actively participate in official decision-making processes – which is a goal that was unexpectedly reached, regardless of the continuous security threats and instability. Syrian youth were exposed to democratic principles, and clarified the roles, rights and responsibilities of an active citizen within a civil society’s formal and democratic decision making processes. Through the value trip, group discussions, the planned activities at the end of each topic these activities contributed to integrate the values into the social actions. More than 80 events were launched by group/clubs’ members. Each event gathered about 12 members from each group which means (42%) 720 out of 1698 members were active in the events reflecting citizenships value.
Around 25 success stories came out from clubs and groups reflect the citizenship values, which means (22%) of groups and clubs out of 107 groups and clubs have a success stories reflecting the citizenship values documented by the facilitator. where we went behind the proposed objective, that's around 20 % of participants reflect the values of citizenship in different ways
Young people also strengthened their ability to identify policies, organize and influence policy-making processes, through offering technical and moral support to constructive civil action. About 60 small initiatives were implemented in Syria, each one of these were addressing one of the community priorities identified by youth groups as a result of the program empowerment and raised awareness. The program team has a full documentation of each initiative and the analysis of the community needs to be included in each initiative folder.
In line with the proposed objective, FADA groups are now able to identify priorities for advocacy and development of communities
Also, to emphasize the dire importance of cross-sectarian civic discussions and support to the engagement of the Syrian youth in such exchanges. The capacity of youth to engage in dialogues between communities have been increased. Through the initiatives led by Youth and adolescents, and the selection processes to support initiatives were democratic and participatory depending on open voting system. 11 initiatives out of the 61 where focusing directly on acceptance, diversity, tolerance, citizenship & democracy and the reset where target these topics in indirect way. In line with the objective, Initiatives led by youth participants focused on acceptance, diversity, tolerance, citizenship & democracy.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
